newsitem.title: SPAIN: Rato said no need for Spain to adjust budget.
newsitem.headline: Rato said no need for Spain to adjust budget.

text.p: Spain's Economy Minister Rodrigo Rato said on Tuesday it would not be necessary to make a budget adjustment mid-stream.
"At this moment the government doesn't see a cutback (of expenditure)," Rato told Parliament.
"The Popular Party is not carrying out a policy of adjustment but one of macroeconomic stability. We are not about to make hard or permanent adjustments or anything like that," he said.
Rato said revenue and expenditures were "satisfactory" in the first quarter of the year.
Rato dismissed opposition criticism that reducing the deficit below two percent of GDP in 2000 would mean a cut in social spending.
"We are reducing the deficit while keeping key social policies," he said.
He added that the stability plan for 3.2 percent on average GDP growth through the year 2000 "is perfectly sustainable."
